question:
Title: Hospitality - Hotel Operations Management (H133) Program Information
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Program Name: Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management
Code: H133
Credential: Ontario College Diploma

Method of Study:
- Full-time

Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)

Starting Months:
- January, May, September

Domestic Tuition: $4,459.00 *
International Tuition: $18,364.00 **

Location: St. James Campus

Experiential Learning: Hybrid (Fall 2023 - Winter 2024)

Program Overview:
The Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management program provides students with exposure to current and best practices in front office, food and beverage, marketing and sales, conferences and event planning, retirement homes, and branded residences. Students will have the opportunity to earn industry certifications such as food safety, responsible alcohol beverage service, and first aid (CPR). In their fourth semester, students will complete a 14-week industry externship.

Related Programs:
- Tourism and Hospitality Management (H130)
- Event Planning (H141)
- Food and Beverage Management – Restaurant Management (H132)

* Domestic tuition might be subject to change based on the specific intake or student status.
** International tuition is for new students. Returning international students may have different tuition rates.?

context:
The George Brown College Hotel Operations Management program is a 14-week industry externship where students complete their placement in a nationwide or international location. This opportunity provides real-world experience and helps students build industry contacts. During their final capstone project, students participate in a hotel operations management simulation to apply their acquired skills.

The European Study Tour is an optional program for students to visit top hotels in Europe to enhance their international hotel management skills. In their fourth semester, students complete the 14-week industry externship as part of their field education.

Graduates of the program gain skills to be progressive leaders within the industry and receive industry certifications in food safety, responsible alcohol beverage service, and first aid (CPR). Students have the flexibility to switch into any hospitality and tourism management programs by their second year, should their interest change. Additionally, graduates are eligible to earn a one-year certificate in Hospitality Services (H101) if they cannot complete their final year of study.

Employment opportunities are abundant in Toronto's hotel industry, with over 38,000 hotel rooms and over 200 hotels. Many graduates work in supervisory and management positions in major hotels nationwide and internationally, while others have reached high-level corporate positions in large hotel chains. Career opportunities also exist in restaurants, casinos, luxury retirement homes, cruise ships, convention centres, entertainment complexes, clubs, bed and breakfasts, catering companies, and conference services.

Graduates of the Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management program may be eligible to enter the Honours Bachelor degree program.
question:
Title: George Brown College - Hospitality Management: Hotel Operations (Toronto, Canada)

Description:
The Hospitality Management: Hotel Operations program at George Brown College is designed to provide students with the skills and knowledge necessary to succeed in various roles within the hotel industry. Students will gain a solid foundation in all aspects of hotel operations, including front desk services, housekeeping, food and beverage management, revenue management, sales and marketing, human resources, and finance.

The program consists of both theoretical and practical components, with students spending time in classrooms and laboratories as well as completing industry externships. Students have the opportunity to participate in an optional European Study Tour to enhance their international hotel management skills. The program is 14 weeks long and includes a capstone project where students apply their acquired skills in a hotel operations management simulation.

Graduates of the program will be prepared for careers as progressive leaders within the industry, with opportunities in hotels, resorts, casinos, restaurants, cruise ships, and more. They will also receive industry certifications in food safety, responsible alcohol beverage service, and first aid (CPR). Students have the flexibility to switch into any hospitality and tourism management programs by their second year should their interest change. Additionally, graduates are eligible to earn a one-year certificate in Hospitality Services if they cannot complete their final year of study.

Employment opportunities abound in Toronto's hotel industry, with over 38,000 hotel rooms and over 200 hotels. Graduates may work in supervisory and management positions in major hotels nationwide and internationally or reach high-level corporate positions in large hotel chains.

Program Structure:
The Hospitality Management: Hotel Operations program is a 14-week industry externship where students complete their placement in a national or international location. The program includes the following courses:

- Hotel Front Desk Services and Reservation Systems
- Hotel Housekeeping and Facility Management
- Food and Beverage Management
- Revenue Management for Hotels and Resorts
- Sales, Marketing, and Communications
- Human Resource Management in Hospitality
- Financial Management for Hotel Operations

Optional European Study Tour:
The European Study Tour is an optional program for students to visit top hotels in Europe and enhance their international hotel management skills. The tour includes visits to hotels in cities such as London, Paris, Amsterdam, and Prague, among others.

Graduates of the Program:
Graduates of the Hospitality Management: Hotel Operations program may be eligible to enter the Honours Bachelor degree program. They will have the skills and knowledge necessary for careers as hotel managers, front office agents, housekeeping supervisors, food and beverage managers, revenue managers, sales and marketing coordinators, event planners, and more.

Employment Opportunities:
Graduates may find employment opportunities in hotels, resorts, casinos, restaurants, cruise ships, convention centers, entertainment complexes, clubs, bed and breakfasts, catering companies, and conference services. They may also work in various roles within large hotel chains or reach high-level corporate positions.

Certifications:
Graduates will receive industry certifications in food safety, responsible alcohol beverage service, and first aid (CPR).

Admission Requirements:
Applicants must have an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent or be 19 years of age or older. They must also complete the George Brown College admission assessment test.

Application Process:
Interested applicants can apply online through the George Brown College website. The application fee is $65 CAD. Applicants may also be required to attend an interview and provide references.

Tuition and Financial Aid:
The tuition for the Hospitality Management: Hotel Operations program is approximately $12,000 CAD per year. Financial aid and scholarships are available to eligible students. Students can apply for OSAP (Ontario Student Assistance Program) to help cover tuition and living expenses.

Contact Information:
George Brown College
School of Hospitality and Tourism Management
51 Dundas Street East, Toronto, ON M5G 2V6, Canada
Email: [info@georgebrown.ca](mailto:info@georgebrown.ca)
Phone: +1 (416) 415-2000
Website: <https://www.georgebrown.ca/hospitality-tourism/programs/hotel-management/>?

context:
Extraction:
- Graduates of Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management program may be eligible to enter the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree program at George Brown College as an advanced standing student in September or January.
- Educational path requires a minimum grade point average of 2.7 to qualify.
- Transfer Guide is available for further information.
- The following courses are required in Semester 1: HOST1085, Principles of Hospitality and Tourism Management; HOSF1171, Global Accommodation Industry; HOST1172, Introduction to Wines and Beverages; HOST1170, Introduction to Catering; HOST1068, Smart Serve (online certificate); HOSF1145, Sanitation (online certificate); HOSF1146, Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course).
- The following courses are required in Semester 2: HOST1174, Remarkable Restaurant Service – An Introduction to the Industry; HOST1043, Special Events Planning and Delivery; HOST1173, Hospitality Marketing and Social Media; HOST1160, Career Preparation; HOST1175, Global Tourism Geography*; HRM1015, Human Resources Management*; LAW1017, Introduction to Hospitality Law*; ACCT1048, Hospitality Accounting*.
- The following courses are required in Semester 3: ACCT2017, Managerial Accounting; HOST1150, Food and Beverage Cost Control; HOST1193, Strategic Revenue Management; HOSF1095, Front Office Operations; HOST2036, Housekeeping and Facilities Management; HOST1192, Retirement Community Management*; HOST1066, Mixology*.
- Semester 4 includes HOST2084, Hotel Investment Capstone Project (online); HOST2133, Industry Externship; and a GNED General Education Elective.

* Denotes courses with an asterisk are not part of the Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management program but are required for the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree.
question:
It appears that graduates of the Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management diploma program at George Brown College can apply to enter the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree program as an advanced standing student, with certain requirements and course prerequisites to be met. The advanced standing option allows students to complete their bachelor's degree in fewer semesters than if they were starting from scratch.

To be eligible for the advanced standing admission into the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) program, applicants must have a minimum grade point average of 2.7 or higher in their Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management diploma studies. They are also required to complete specific courses in their final semester as prerequisites for certain courses in the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) program.

The following courses are required for Semesters 1 and 2: HOST1085, Principles of Hospitality and Tourism Management; HOSF1171, Global Accommodation Industry; HOST1172, Introduction to Wines and Beverages; HOST1170, Introduction to Catering; HOST1068, Smart Serve (online certificate); HOSF1145, Sanitation (online certificate); HOSF1146, Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course); HOST1174, Remarkable Restaurant Service – An Introduction to the Industry; HOST1043, Special Events Planning and Delivery; HOST1173, Hospitality Marketing and Social Media; HOST1160, Career Preparation; HOST1192, Retirement Community Management*; and HOST1066, Mixology*.

Semester 3 courses include: ACCT1048, Hospitality Accounting; HOST1150, Food and Beverage Cost Control; HOST1193, Strategic Revenue Management; HOSF1095, Front Office Operations; HOST1192, Retirement Community Management*; and HOST1175, Global Tourism Geography*.

Semester 4 requirements include: ACCT2017, Managerial Accounting; HOST2036, Housekeeping and Facilities Management; and a GNED General Education Elective. Additionally, students must complete an online course, HOST2084, Hotel Investment Capstone Project, in their final semester and an Industry Externship (HOST2133) during one of the previous semesters.

It's important to note that courses marked with an asterisk (*) are not part of the Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management diploma program but are required for the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree. Students should consult the George Brown College Transfer Guide or speak with an academic advisor for further details regarding the application process and course requirements.?

context:
Program Offered: Industry Externship (INDSTRY EXTERNSHIP) under General Education Electives (GENED)

Course Format: seven-week courses

Mandatory Course: COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) for some students, does not count towards graduation and additional charge

General Education Elective Course Outlines and Program Learning Outcomes available at Assessment Centre

Learning Outcomes for the Graduate:
1. Adopt a positive attitude and professional decorum, accommodate diverse and special needs, contribute as a team member
2. Deliver customer service and solutions that anticipate, meet and/or exceed individual expectations, organizational expectations, standards and objectives
3. Use marketing concepts, market research, social networks, sales and revenue management strategies, relationship management skills and product knowledge to promote and sell hospitality services, products and guest experiences
4. Apply business and revenue models as well as basic accounting, budgeting, financial and administration skills to support the effective management and operation of a variety of organizations delivering hospitality services and products
5. Comply with relevant organization and workplace systems, processes, policies, standards, legal obligations and regulations, and apply risk management principles to support and maintain efficient, safe, secure, accessible and healthy hospitality operations
6. Use appropriate technologies to enhance the quality and delivery of hospitality services, products and guest experiences and to measure the effectiveness of hospitality operations
7. Keep current with hospitality trends and issues, and interdependent relationships in the broader tourism industry sectors to improve work performance and guide career development
8. Use leadership, teamwork, conflict and relationship management skills and tools, as well as knowledge of organizational behaviour, labour relations, employment standards and human rights to contribute to a positive work environment
9. Respond to issues and dilemmas arising in the delivery of hospitality services, products and guest experiences by using and promoting ethical behaviour and best practices of corporate social responsibility and environmental sustainability

Tuition & Fees:
Domestic Tuition: $4,459.00  *(Fall 2022 for first two semesters)
International Tuition: $18,364.00 *(Fall 2022 for first two semesters)

Additional Costs: subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates

Note: † Indicates that tuition fees listed are for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022 only.
question:
Here's a summary of the Hospitality Management diploma program information you provided:

Program Name: Hospitality Management Diploma
Duration: Two years (four semesters)
Program Type: Diploma
Credits: 60 credits

Program Description:
This two-year Hospitality Management diploma program is designed to provide students with the foundational knowledge and skills required for entry-level positions in various hospitality sectors. The program includes both theoretical and practical components, allowing students to gain hands-on experience through industry externships and real-world applications. Students will learn about marketing, sales, revenue management, financial and administrative skills, customer service, organizational behavior, labor relations, employment standards, human rights, ethical behavior, corporate social responsibility, environmental sustainability, and more.

Program Format:
The program consists of seven-week courses. Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) as a mandatory course, which does not count towards graduation and requires an additional charge.

General Education Electives:
Industry Externship (INDSTRY EXTERNSHIP) is offered as a General Education Elective under the GENED category.

Mandatory Course:
COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) for some students, does not count towards graduation and additional charge.

Course Format:
Seven-week courses.

Tuition & Fees:
Domestic Students: $4,459.00 (Fall 2022 for the first two semesters)
International Students: $18,364.00 (Fall 2022 for the first two semesters)

Note that tuition fees listed are for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022 only. Additional costs may apply for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.

Learning Outcomes:
Upon completion of this program, graduates will be able to:
1. Adopt a positive attitude and professional decorum, accommodate diverse and special needs, contribute as a team member.
2. Deliver customer service and solutions that anticipate, meet and/or exceed individual expectations, organizational expectations, standards, and objectives.
3. Use marketing concepts, market research, social networks, sales and revenue management strategies, relationship management skills, and product knowledge to promote and sell hospitality services, products, and guest experiences.
4. Apply business and revenue models as well as basic accounting, budgeting, financial, and administration skills to support the effective management and operation of a variety of organizations delivering hospitality services and products.
5. Comply with relevant organization and workplace systems, processes, policies, standards, legal obligations, and regulations and apply risk management principles to support and maintain efficient, safe, secure, accessible, and healthy hospitality operations.
6. Use appropriate technologies to enhance the quality and delivery of hospitality services, products, and guest experiences and to measure the effectiveness of hospitality operations.
7. Keep current with hospitality trends and issues and interdependent relationships in the broader tourism industry sectors to improve work performance and guide career development.
8. Use leadership, teamwork, conflict and relationship management skills and tools as well as knowledge of organizational behavior, labor relations, employment standards, and human rights to contribute to a positive work environment.
9. Respond to issues and dilemmas arising in the delivery of hospitality services, products, and guest experiences by using and promoting ethical behavior and best practices of corporate social responsibility and environmental sustainability.?

context:
The text provides information about tuition fees for programs starting in Fall 2023 at George Brown College. Here are the key factual points extracted from the text:

* Amounts listed are the total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023.
* The amounts are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates.
* Textbooks and manuals cost an additional $575 (subject to change).
* International students should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
* The program is approved for OSAP funding, but applicants must meet eligibility criteria.
* Applicants require an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, Grade 12 English (C or U).
* Mature students may apply with no OSSD and take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade their English skills.
* College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions.
* International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Health policy states that allergens, including nuts, dairy and shellfish, are used in practical labs. George Brown is sensitive to religious observances but cannot guarantee dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods will be met.
* Domestic students should follow the instructions on how to apply provided later in the text.
question:
Title: Tuition Fees for Fall 2023 Programs at George Brown College

George Brown College has released the tuition fees for programs commencing in Fall 2023. The following information pertains to the total cost of tuition, materials, student services, and ancillary fees for the first two semesters:

1. Tuition fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and beyond.
2. International students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for additional information.
3. Textbooks and manuals will cost an extra $575 (subject to modification).
4. The program is eligible for OSAP funding; however, applicants must meet eligibility requirements.
5. Applicants need a valid Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with a minimum Grade 12 English requirement of C or U.
6. Mature students may apply without an OSSD and take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade their English skills.
7. College or university credits may grant course exemptions.
8. International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
9. The Health Policy indicates that allergens, including nuts, dairy, and shellfish, are used in practical labs. George Brown is considerate of religious observances but cannot ensure dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods will be met.
10. Domestic students should follow the provided instructions on how to apply.

Please note that tuition fees for specific programs can be found on the George Brown College website, under the Programs, Courses & Schedules section.?
